formalText: He's going to a conference next week and making a poster.
He finished the poster last night.
The making process is so exciting for him because he doesn't like making mistakes, and he doesn't like correcting it in large letters when there are mistakes.
So he's very careful not to make mistakes, but there's also some not well-defined apprehension about the experience of presenting the poster.
He feels strangely comfort and joy, like delighted by the process that we went through there.
He finds it amusing that that was how it went.
But he's also really pleased that that was very nice and he really appreciates me doing what I do and saying what I said.
He thinks it's comforting to have the problem understood thoroughly and the long-range answer to it described in careful detail.

He thinks, how does that make him feel so that he can sort of dwell on what it might look like to go along the path, to think about the intervening time between here and there and where everything stands.
And he knows that it had sorrow and hardship and all of that attached.
But it's okay because it's going somewhere.
It would be really nice for him to feel things that are good even if not ideal.
He thinks that's a hard problem.
Tanya disclosed that she was still suicidal on a regular basis-multiple times a week.
He doesn't think she's correct about that.
He thinks there was a period
of time where it certainly was not every couple or three days.
Clearly it was deeply upsetting.
He feels like he should have a general sense of that, and often he does without her saying anything, just living with her.
He also feels like
I'm not telling him it's a sign of her not trusting him to do something or handle something.
He sure sounds discouraged.
Talking about it is making him feel discouraged, or at least it's that the emotion is bubbling up.
He doesn't have a very clear sense of a strategy that will win out in the end.
Just keep doing this.
He'll come here.
She'll see Josh.
Go to couples counseling.

He thinks discouraged is right.
He tries to think about the other things since that's not going to go anywhere.
He wants to think about something else.
He thinks he'd like uncertainty to be bounded.
He certainly doesn't know where they'll end up or where he will end up.
It would be really nice for him to feel things that are good even if not ideal.
Equating non-ideal descriptions with situations that are bad is exactly the problem we're trying to address.
He thinks that's a hard problem.
And it shows up in so many areas of his life.
He talked about it with respect to his career and how the option seems bad because there were some  fundamental flaws.
He thinks he normally makes a distinction between ideal and some range of okay and then some other range of really not.
Ideally he would have married the person that he thought he married and she wouldn't be suicidal and she would embrace the same values that he has, and that's ideal.
That's not going to happen.
They started couples counseling last week, but they're still feeling out
Dr. Janice to figure out if he's the right person or not.
He's been living with her for a while.
On the one hand, he's not surprised in the context of the last several weeks.
He thinks he mentioned that he thought she had not been doing that.
It's not such big of a surprise that they claim it's an unbroken string back to March.
He feels like he should have a general sense of that, and often he does without her saying anything, just living with her.
She suggested that she thought she told him or that he knew. He's not really sure that that's not reasonable.
But he doesn't know.
He thinks on any particular day when she's not well, he can either handle it just fine, or he feels like there's nothing that they're going to do that day
that's any different from the last time they did exactly the same day, and nothing's changed.
Realistically, he thinks she's coping with it better in the sense that if the claim is true,
she's been off and on suicidal for several months without being hospitalized.
Certainly, her mood has not been as dire as it has been in most of the hospitalization circumstances because it's obvious when her mood is that bad.

So one of the main ways he combats guys is to think about the other conference that he went to where the things he was talking about,
he was not particularly pleased with the work.
He was pleased when they got to the point they had gotten to
But it was mostly the things they were trying really didn't work.
What is a vaguely depressing experience, very depressing experience, but satisfying to be able to bury it in that way.
He found that it was a well-received experience, but was vaguely awkward because he didn't know anybody, but it's fine.
So he can fairly well predict what it's going to be like, even though he's never been to this particular conference.
